This pointer pattern extracts book and chapter.

castItem.roleDesc: a sea captain, friend to Sebastian

set.p: A city in Illyria, and the sea-coast near it.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage:
Enter DUKE, CURIO, and other
Lords; Musicians attending.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: If music be the food of love, play on;
Give me excess of it, that, surfeiting,
The appetite may sicken, and so die.
That strain again! it had a dying fall:
O, it came o'er my ear like the sweet sound,
That breathes upon a bank of violets,
Stealing and giving odor! Enough; no more:
'Tis not so sweet now as it was before.
O spirit of love! how quick and fresh art thou,
That, notwithstanding thy capacity
Receiveth as the sea, nought enters there,
Of what validity and pitch soe'er,
But falls into abatement and low price,
Even in a minute: so full of shapes is fancy
That it alone is high fantastical.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Will you go hunt, my lord?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What, Curio?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: The hart.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why, so I do, the noblest that I have:
O, when mine eyes did see Olivia first,
Methought she purged the air of pestilence!
That instant was I turn'd into a hart;
And my desires, like fell and cruel hounds,
E'er since pursue me. Enter VALENTINE.
How now! what news from her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: So please my lord, I might not be admitted;
But from her handmaid do return this answer:
The element itself, till seven years' heat,
Shall not behold her face at ample view;
But, like a cloistress, she will veiled walk
And water once a day her chamber round
With eye-offending brine: all this to season
A brother's dead love, which she would keep fresh
And lasting in her sad remembrance.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, she that hath a heart of that fine frame
To pay this debt of love but to a brother,
How will she love, when the rich golden shaft
Hath kill'd the flock of all affections else
That live in her; when liver, brain and heart,
These sovereign thrones, are all supplied, and fill'd
Her sweet perfections with one self king!
Away before me to sweet beds of flowers:

Love-thoughts lie rich when canopied with bowers.
[Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II
div.stage: Enter VIOLA, a Captain, and Sailors.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What country, friends, is this?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: This is Illyria, lady.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And what should I do in Illyria?
My brother he is in Elysium.
Perchance he is not drown'd: what think you, sailors?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: It is perchance that you yourself were saved.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: O my poor brother! and so perchance may he be.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: True, madam: and, to comfort you with chance,
Assure yourself, after our ship did split,
When you and those poor number saved with you
Hung on our driving boat, I saw your brother,
Most provident in peril, bind himself,
Courage and hope both teaching him the practice,
To a strong mast that lived upon the sea;
Where, like Arion on the dolphin's back,
I saw him hold acquaintance with the waves
So long as I could see.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: For saying so, there's gold:
Mine own escape unfoldeth to my hope,
Whereto thy speech serves for authority,
The like of him. Know'st thou this country?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Ay, madam, well; for I was bred and born
Not three hours' travel from this very place.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Who governs here?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A noble duke, in nature as in name.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Orsino.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Orsino! I have heard my father name him:
He was a bachelor then.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: And so is now, or was so very late;
For but a month ago I went from hence,
And then 'twas fresh in murmur,—as, you know,
What great ones do the less will prattle of,—
That he did seek the love of fair Olivia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What's she?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count
That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her
In the protection of his son, her brother,
Who shortly also died: for whose dear love,
They say, she hath abjured the company
And sight of men.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: O that I served that lady
And might not be delivered to the world,
Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,
What my estate is!

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: That were hard to compass;
Becaue she will admit no kind of suit,
No, not the duke's.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: There is a fair behavior in thee, captain;
And though that nature with a beauteous wall
Doth oft close in pollution, yet of thee
I will believe thou hast a mind that suits
With this thy fair and outward character.
I prithee, and I'll pay thee bounteously,
Conceal me what I am, and be my aid
For such disguise as haply shall become
The form of my intent. I'll serve this duke:
Thou shalt present me as an eunuch to him:
It may be worth thy pains; for I can sing
And speak to him in many sorts of music
That will allow me very worth his service.
What else may hap to time I will commit;
Only shape thou thy silence to my wit.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Be you his eunuch, and your mute I'll be:
When my tongue blabs, then let mine eyes not see.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thank thee: lead me on. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III
div.stage: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH and MARIA.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What a plague means my niece, to
take the
death of her brother thus? I am sure
care's an enemy to
life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
By my troth, Sir Toby, you must
come in earlier
o' nights: your cousin, my
lady, takes great exceptions
to your ill hours.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Why, let her except, before excepted.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Ay, but you must confine yourself
within the
modest limits of order.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Confine! I'll confine myself no
finer than I am:
these clothes are good enough
to drink in; and so be
these boots too: an
they be not, let them hang themselves
in their
own straps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
That quaffing and drinking will undo
you: I
heard my lady talk of it yesterday;
and of a foolish
knight that you brought in one
night here to be her wooer.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Ay, he.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: He's as tall a man as any's in Illyria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What's that to the purpose?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l:
Why, he has three thousand ducats
a year.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Ay, but he'll have but a year in all
these ducats:
he's a very fool and a prodigal.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Fie, that you'll say so! he plays o'
the viol-de-gamboys,
and speaks three or four
languages word for word
without book, and
hath all the good gifts of nature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He hath indeed, almost natural: for
besides that
he's a fool, he's a great quarreller:
and but that he hath
the gift of a coward to
allay the gust he hath in quarrelling,
'tis
thought among the prudent he would quickly
have the gift of a grave.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
By this hand, they are scoundrels
and substractors
that say so of him. Who are
they?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
They that add, moreover, he's drunk
nightly
in your company.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
With drinking healths to my niece:
I'll drink
to her as long as there is a passage
in my throat and drink
in Illyria: he's a coward
and a coystrill that will not
drink to my
niece till his brains turn o' the toe like a
parish-top. What, wench! Castiliano vulgo!
for here comes
Sir Andrew Agueface.
Enter SIR ANDREW AGUECHEEK.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Sir Toby Belch! how now, Sir
Toby Belch!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Sweet Sir Andrew!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: Bless you, fair shrew.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And you too, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: My niece's chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Good Mistress Accost, I desire
better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My name is Mary, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: Good Mistress Mary Accost,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
You mistake, knight; 'accost' is
front her, board
her, woo her, assail her.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
By my troth, I would not undertake
her in this
company. Is that the meaning
of 'accost '?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fare you well, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
An thou let part so, Sir Andrew,
would thou
mightst never draw sword again.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
An you part so, mistress, I would
I might never
draw sword again. Fair lady,
do you think you have
fools in hand?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, I have not you by the hand.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Marry, but you shall have; and
here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Now, sir, 'thought is free:' I pray
you, bring your
hand to the buttery-bar and
let it drink.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Wherefore, sweet-heart? what's
your
metaphor?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It's dry, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Why, I think so: I am not such
an ass but I
can keep my hand dry. But what's
your jest?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A dry jest, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Are you full of them?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers'
ends: marry, now
I let go your hand, I am
barren. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
O knight, thou lackest a cup of
canary: when did
I see thee so put down?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Never in your life, I think; unless
you see canary
put me down. Methinks sometimes
I have no
more wit than a Christian or
an ordinary man has: but I
am a great eater
of beef and I believe that does harm
to my wit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: No question.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
An I thought that, I'ld forswear
it. I'll ride
home to-morrow, Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
What is 'pourquoi'? do or not
do? I would I had
bestowed that time in the
tongues that I have in fencing,
dancing and
bear-baiting: O, had I but followed the
arts!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Then hadst thou had an excellent
head of hair.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Why, would that have mended
my hair?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Past question; for thou seest it will
not curl by nature.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
But it becomes me well enough,
does't not?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Excellent; it hangs like flax on a
distaff; and I hope
to see a housewife take
thee between her legs and spin it off.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Faith, I'll home to-morrow, Sir
Toby: your niece will
not be seen; or if she
be, it's four to one she'll none of me: the
count himself here hard by woos her.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
She'll none o' the count: she'll not
match above her
degree, neither in estate,
years, nor wit; I have heard her
swear't. Tut,
there's life in 't, man.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
I'll stay a month longer. I am a
fellow o' the
strangest mind i' the world; I delight
in masques and revels
sometimes altogether.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Art thou good at these kickshawses,
knight?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
As any man in Illyria, whatsoever
he be, under
the degree of my betters;
and yet I will not compare with
an old man.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What is thy excellence in a galliard,
knight?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Faith, I can cut a caper.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: And I can cut the mutton to't.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
And I think I have the back-trick
simply as
strong as any man in Illyria.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Wherefore are these things hid?
wherefore have
these gifts a curtain before
'em? are they like to take
dust, like Mistress
Mall's picture? why dost thou not go
to
church in a galliard and come home in a coranto?
My very walk should be a jig; I would
not so much
as make water but in a sink-a-pace.
What dost thou
mean? Is it a world to
hide virtues in? I did think, by
the excellent
constitution of thy leg, it was formed under
the star of a galliard.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Ay, 'tis strong, and it does indifferent
well in a
flame-colored stock. Shall we
set about some revels?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What shall we do else? were we
not born under
Taurus?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Taurus! That's sides and heart.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
No, sir; it is legs and thighs. Let
me see thee caper:
ha! higher: ha, ha! excellent! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV
div.stage: Enter VALENTINE, and VIOLA in man's attire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
If the duke continue these favors towards
you,
Cesario, you are like to be much
advanced: he hath known
you but three days,
and already you are no stranger.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
You either fear his humor or my negligence,
that you call in question the continuance
of his love: is he
inconstant, sir, in his
favors?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: No, believe me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I thank you. Here comes the count. Enter DUKE, CURIO, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Who saw Cesario, ho?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: On your attendance, my lord; here.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Stand you a while aloof, Cesario,
Thou know'st no less but all; I have unclasp'd
To thee the book even of my secret soul:
Therefore, good youth, address thy gait unto her;
Be not denied access, stand at her doors,
And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow
Till thou have audience.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sure, my noble lord,
If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow
As it is spoke, she never will admit me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be clamorous and leap all civil bounds
Rather than make uprofited return.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Say I do speak with her, my lord, what then?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, then unfold the passion of my love,
Surprise her with discourse of my dear faith:
It shall become thee well to act my woes;
She will attend it better in thy youth
Than in a nuncio's of more grave aspect.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I think not so, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dear lad, believe it;
For they shall yet belie thy happy years,
That say thou art a man: Diana's lip
Is not more smooth and rubious; thy small pipe
Is as the maiden's organ, shrill and sound,
And all is semblative a woman's part.
I know thy constellation is right apt
For this affair. Some four or five attend him;
All, if you will; for I myself am best
When least in company. Prosper well in this,
And thou shalt live as freely as thy lord,
To call his fortunes thine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I'll do my best
To woo your lady: [Aside] yet, a barful strife!
Whoe'er I woo, myself would be his wife. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, either tell me where thou hast
been, or I will
not open my lips so wide as a
bristle may enter in way
of thy excuse: my
lady will hang thee for thy absence.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Let her hang me: he that is well
hanged in this
world needs to fear no colors.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Make that good.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: He shall see none to fear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
A good lenten answer: I can tell
thee where that
saying was born, of 'I fear no
colors.'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Where, good Mistress Mary?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
In the wars; and that may you be
bold to say in
your foolery.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well, God give them wisdom that
have it; and
those that are fools, let them use
their talents.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Yet you will be hanged for being so
long absent;
or to be turned away, is not that
as good as a hanging to
you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Many a good hanging prevents a bad
marriage;
and, for turning away, let summer
bear it out.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are resolute, then?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Not so, neither; but I am resolved on
two points.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
That if one break, the other will
hold; or, if both
break, your gaskins fall.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Apt, in good faith; very apt. Well,
go thy way; if
Sir Toby would leave drinking,
thou wert as witty a piece
of Eve's flesh as
any in Illyria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Peace, you rogue, no more o' that.
Here comes my
lady: make your excuse
wisely, you were best. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Wit, an't be thy will, put me into
good fooling!
Those wits, that think they have
thee, do very oft prove
fools; and I, that am
sure I lack thee, may pass for a
wise man: for
what says Quinapalus? 'Better a witty fool,
than a foolish wit.' Enter Lady OLIVIA with MALVOLIO.
God bless thee, lady!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Take the fool away.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Do you not hear, fellows? Take away
the lady.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Go to, you're a dry fool; I'll no more
of you: besides,
you grow dishonest.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Two faults, madonna, that drink and
good counsel
will amend: for give the dry fool
drink, then is the fool
not dry; bid the dishonest
man mend himself; if he mend,
he is
no longer dishonest; if he cannot let the
botcher
mend him. Any thing that's mended
is but patched: virtue
that transgresses is but
patched with sin; and sin that amends
is but
patched with virtue. If that this simple
syllogism
will serve, so; if it will not, what remedy?
As there is no true cuckold but calamity,
so beauty's a
flower. The lady bade take
away the fool; therefore, I
say again, take her away.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Sir, I bade them take away you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Misprision in the highest degree!
Lady, cucullus
non facit monachum; that's as
much to say as I wear not
motley in my brain.
Good madonna, give me leave to
prove you a
fool.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Can you do it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Dexteriously, good madonna.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Make your proof.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I must catechize you for it, madonna:
good my
mouse of virtue, answer me.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Well, sir, for want of other idleness,
I'll bide your
proof.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Good madonna, why mournest thou?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Good fool, for my brother's death.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I think his soul is in hell, madonna.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I know his soul is in heaven, fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The more fool, madonna, to mourn
for your
brother's soul being in heaven. Take
away the fool,
gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
What think you of this fool,Malvolio?
doth he
not mend?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Yes, and shall do till the pangs of
death shake
him: infirmity, that decays the
wise, doth ever make the
better fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
God send you, sir, a speedy infirmity,
for the
better increasing your folly! Sir Toby
will be sworn that
I am no fox; but he will
not pass his word for two pence
that you are
no fool.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: How say you to that, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I marvel your ladyship takes delight
in such
a barren rascal: I saw him put down
the other day with
an ordinary fool that has
no more brain than a stone.
Look you now,
he's out of his guard already; unless you
laugh and minister occasion to him, he is
gagged. I protest,
I take these wise men, that
crow so at these set kind of
fools, no better
than the fools' zanies.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Oh, you are sick of self-love,Malvolio,
and taste
with a distempered appetite. To
be generous, guiltless
and of free disposition,
is to take those things for bird-bolts
that you
deem cannon-bullets: there is no slander
in
an allowed fool, though he do nothing but
rail;
nor no railing in a known discreet man,
though he do
nothing but reprove.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now Mercury endue thee with leasing,
for thou
speakest well of fools!
Re-enter MARIA.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Madam, there is at the gate a young
gentleman
much desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: From the Count Orsino, is it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I know not, madam: 'tis a fair
young man, and
well attended.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Who of my people hold him in delay?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir Toby, madam, your kinsman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Fetch him off, I pray you; he speaks
nothng but
madman: fie on him! [Exit
Maria.] Go you, Malvolio: if it be a suit
from the count, I am sick, or not at home;
what you
will, to dismiss it. [Exit Malvolio.]
Now you see, sir, how your fooling grows old,
and people
dislike it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Thou hast spoke for us, madonna, as
if thy eldest
son should be a fool; whose skull
Jove cram with
brains! for,—here he comes,
—
one of thy kin has a most weak pia mater. Enter SIR TOBY.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
By mine honor, half drunk. What is
he at the
gate, cousin?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: A gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: A gentleman! what gentleman?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Tis a gentleman here—a plague o'
these pickle-herring!
How now, sot!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Good Sir Toby!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Cousin, cousin, how have you come
so early by
this lethargy?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Lechery! I defy lechery. There's
one at the
gate.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ay, marry, what is he?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Let him be the devil, an he will, I
care not: give
me faith, say I. Well, it's all
one. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What's a drunken man like, fool?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Like a drowned man, a fool and a
mad man:
one draught above heat makes him
a fool; the second
mads him; and a third
drowns him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Go thou and seek the crowner, and
let him sit
o' my coz; for he's in the third degree
of drink, he's
drowned: go, look after
him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
He is but mad yet, madonna; and the
fool shall
look to the madman. [Exit.
Re-enter MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Madam, yond young fellow swears he
will
speak with you. I told him you were sick;
he takes on
him to understand so much, and
therefore comes to speak
with you. I told him
you were asleep; he seems to have
a foreknowledge
of that too, and therefore comes
to
speak with you. What is to be said to him,
lady? he's
fortified against any denial.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Tell him he shall not speak with me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Has been told so; and he says, he'll
stand at
your door like a sheriff's post, and be
the supporter to
a bench, but he'll speak with
you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What kind o' man is he?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why, of mankind.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What manner of man?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Of very ill manner; he'll speak with
you, will
you or no.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Of what personage and years is he?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Not yet old enough for a man, nor
young enough
for a boy; as a squash is before
'tis a peascod, or a codling
when 'tis almost
an apple: 'tis with him in standing
water,
between boy and man. He is very well-favored
and he speaks very shrewishly; one
would think his
mother's milk were scarce out
of him.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Let him approach: call in my gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l:
Gentlewoman, my lady calls. [Exit.
Re-enter MARIA.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Give me my veil: come, throw it o'er my face.

We'll once more hear Orsino's embassy.
Enter VIOLA, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
The honorable lady of the house,
which is she?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Speak to me; I shall answer for her.
Your will?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Most radiant, exquisite and unmatchable
beauty,—
I pray you, tell me if this be the
lady of the house,
for I never saw her: I
would be loath to cast away my
speech, for
besides that it is excellently well penned, I
have
taken great pains to con it. Good beauties,
let me sustain
no scorn; I am very
comptible, even to the least
sinister usage.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Whence came you, sir?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I can say little more than I have
studied, and that
question's out of my part.
Good gentle one, give me
modest assurance
if you be the lady of the house, that I
may
proceed in my speech.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Are you a comedian?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
No, my profound heart: and yet, by
the very
fangs of malice I swear, I am not that
I play. Are you
the lady of the house?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: If I do not usurp myself, I am.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Most certain, if you are she, you do
usurp yourself;
for what is yours to bestow is
not yours to reserve.
But this is from my commission:
I will on with
my speech in your
praise, and then show you the heart of
my
message.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Come to what is important in't: I forgive
you
the praise.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Alas, I took great pains to study it,
and 'tis
poetical.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
It is the more like to be feigned: I
pray you, keep
it in. I heard you were saucy
at my gates, and allowed your
approach rather
to wonder at you than to hear you. If
you be
not mad, be gone; if you have reason, be
brief:
'tis not that time of moon with me to
make one in so
skipping a dialogue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Will you hoist sail, sir? here lies
your way.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
No, good swabber; I am to hull here
a little longer.
Some mollification for your
giant, sweet lady.
Tell me your mind: I am
a messenger.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Sure, you have some hideous matter
to deliver,
when the courtesy of it is so fearful.
Speak your office.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
It alone concerns your ear. I bring
no overture
of war, no taxation of homage: I
hold the olive
in my hand; my words are as
full of peace as matter.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Yet you began rudely. What are you?
what would you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
The rudeness that hath appeared in 
me have I 
learned
              from my entertainment. 
What I am, and what I 
would,
              are as secret 
as maidenhead; to your ears, divinity, 
to any 
other's, profanation.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Now, sir, what is your text?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Most sweet lady,—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
A comfortable doctrine, and much
may be said
of it. Where liest your text?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: In Orsino's bosom.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l:
In his bosom! In what chapter of his
bosom?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
To answer by the method, in the first
of his heart.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
O, I have read it: it is heresy. Have
you no more
to say?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Good madam, let me see your face.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Have you any commission from your
lord to
negotiate with my face? You are now
out of your text:
but we will draw the curtain
and show you the picture.
Look you, sir, such
a one I was this present: is't not well
done? [Unveiling.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Excellently done, if God did all.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
'Tis in grain, sir; 'twill endure wind
and
weather.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: 'Tis beauty truly blent, whose red and white
Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on:
Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,
If you will lead these graces to the grave
And leave the world no copy.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
O, sir, I will not be so hard-hearted;
I will give
out divers schedules of my beauty:
it shall be inventoried,
and every particle and
utensil labelled to my will: as,
item, two lips,
indifferent red; item, two grey eyes,
with lids
to them; item, one neck, one chin, and so
forth.
Were you sent hither to praise me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I see you what you are, you are too proud;
But, if you were the devil, you are fair.
My lord and master loves you: O, such love
Could be but recompensed, though you were crown'd
The nonpareil of beauty!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: How does he love me?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: With adorations, fertile tears,
With groans that thunder love, with sighs of fire.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Your lord does know my mind; I cannot love him:
Yet I suppose him virtuous, know him noble,
Of great estate, of fresh and stainless youth;
In voices well divulged, free, learn'd and valiant;
And in dimension and the shape of nature
A gracious person: but yet I cannot love him;
He might have took his answer long ago.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: If I did love you in my master's flame,
With such a suffering, such a deadly life,
In your denial I would find no sense;
I would not understand it.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why, what would you? <

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Make me a willow cabin at your gate,
And call upon my soul within the house;
Write loyal cantons of contemned love
And sing them loud even in the dead of night;
Halloo your name to the reverberate hills
And make the babbling gossip of the air
Cry out 'Olivia!' O, you should not rest
Between the elements of air and earth,
But you should pity me!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: You might do much.
What is your parentage?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:
I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Get you to your lord;
I cannot love him: let him send no more;
Unless, perchance, you come to me again,
To tell me how he takes it. Fare you well:
I thank you for your pains: spend this for me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am no fee'd post, lady; keep your purse:
My master, not myself, lacks recompense.
Love make his heart of flint that you shall love;
And let your fervor, like my master's, be
Placed in contempt! Farewell, fair cruelty. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: 'What is your parentage?
'Above my fortunes, yet my state is well:
I am a gentleman.' I'll be sworn thou art;
Thy tongue, thy face, thy limbs, actions and spirit,
Do give thee five-fold blazon: not too fast: soft, soft!
Unless the master were the man. How now!
Even so quickly may one catch the plague?
Methinks I feel this youth's perfections
With an invisible and subtle stealth
To creep in at mine eyes. Well, let it be.

What ho, Malvolio!
Re-enter MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Here, madam, at your service.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Run after that same peevish messenger,
The county's man: he left this ring behind him,
Would I or not: tell him I'll none of it.
Desire him not to flatter with his lord,
Nor hold him up with hopes; I am not for him:
If that the youth will come this way to-morrow,
I'll give him reasons for't: hie thee, Malvolio.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Madam, I will. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I do I know not what, and fear to find
Mine eye too great a flatterer for my mind.
Fate, show thy force: ourselves we do not owe;

What is decreed must be, and be this so.
[Exit,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Will you stay no longer? nor will you
not that
I go with you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
By your patience, no. My stars shine
darkly
over me: the malignancy of my fate
might perhaps distemper
yours; therefore I
shall crave of you your leave
that I may bear
my evils alone: it were a bad recompense
for
your love, to lay any of them on you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
Let me yet know of you whither you
are bound.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
No, sooth, sir: my determinate voyage
is mere
extravagancy. But I perceive in
you so excellent a touch
of modesty, that you
will not extort from me what I am
willing to
keep in; therefore it charges me in manners
the rather to express myself. You must know
of me
then, Antonio, my name is Sebastian,
which I called Roderigo.
My father was that
Sebastian of Messaline, whom I
know you
have heard of. He left behind him myself
and
a sister, both born in an hour: if the heavens
had
been pleased, would we had so ended!
but you, sir, altered
that; for some hour before
you took me from the
breach of the sea
was my sister drowned.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alas the day!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
A lady, sir, though it was said she
much resembled
me, was yet of many accounted
beautiful: but, though
I could not
with such estimable wonder overfar believe
that, yet thus far I will boldly publish her; she
bore a mind that envy could not but call fair.
She is
drowned already, sir, with salt water,
though I seem to
drown her remembrance
again with more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, your bad entertainment.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O good Antonio, forgive me your trouble.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
If you will not murder me for my
love, let me
be your servant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p:
If you will not undo what you have
done, that is,
kill him whom you have recovered,
desire it not. Fare
ye well at once: my
bosom is full of kindness, and I
am yet so
near the manners of my mother, that upon the
least occasion more mine eyes will tell tales of
me. I am
bound to the Count Orsino's court: farewell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The gentleness of all the gods go with thee!
I have many enemies in Orsino's court,
Else would I very shortly see thee there.
But, come what may, I do adore thee so,
That danger shall seem sport, and I will go. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Were not you even now with the
Countess
Olivia?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Even now, sir; on a moderate pace I
have since arrived
but hither.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
She returns this ring to you, sir: you
might
have saved me my pains, to have taken
it away yourself.
She adds, moreover, that you
should put your lord
into a desperate assurance
she will none of him: and one
thing
more, that you be never so hardy to come
again
in his affairs, unless it be to report your
lord's taking
of this. Receive it so.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: She took the ring of me: I'll none of it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Come, sir, you peevishly threw it to
her; and
her will is, it should be so returned:
if it be worth stooping
for, there it lies in your
eye; if not, be it his that
finds it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I left no ring with her: what means this lady?
Fortune forbid my outside have not charm'd her!
She made good view of me; indeed, so much,
That sure methought her eyes had lost her tongue,
For she did speak in starts distractedly.
She loves me, sure; the cunning of her passion
Invites me in this churlish messenger.
None of my lord's ring! why, he sent her none.
I am the man: if it be so, as 'tis,
Poor lady, she were better love a dream.
Disguise, I see, thou art a wickedness,
Wherein the pregnant enemy does much.
How easy is it for the proper-false
In women's waxen hearts to set their forms!
Alas, our frailty is the cause, not we!
For such as we are made of, such we be.
How will this fadge? 'my master loves her dearly;
And I, poor monster, fond as much on him;
And she, mistaken, seems to dote on me.
What will become of this? As I am man,
My state is desperate for my master's love;
As I am woman,—now alas the day!—
What thriftless sighs shall poor Olivia breathe!
O time! thou must untangle this, not I;
It is too hard a knot for me to untie! [Exit.

div.head: SCENE III
div.stage: Enter SIR TOBY and SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Approach, Sir Andrew: not to be
abed after
midnight is to be up betimes; and
'diluculo surgere,' thou
know'st,—

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Nay, by my troth, I know not: but
I know, to
be up late is to be up late.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
A false conclusion: I hate it as an
unfilled can.
To be up after midnight and to
go to bed then, is early:
so that to go to bed
after midnight is to go to bed betimes.
Does
not our life consist of the four
elements?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Faith, so they say; but I think it
rather consists
of eating and drinking.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Thou'rt a scholar; let us therefore
eat and drink.
Marian, I say! a stoup of wine!
Enter CLOWN.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Here comes the fool, i' faith.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
How now, my hearts! did you never
see the picture
of 'we three'?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Welcome, ass. Now let's have a catch.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
By my troth, the fool has an excellent
breast. I
had rather than forty shillings
I had such a leg, and so
sweet a breath
to sing, as the fool has. In sooth, thou wast
in
very gracious fooling last night, when thou
spokest of
Pigrogromitus, of the Vapians passing
the equinoctial of
Queubus: 'twas very
good, i' faith. I sent thee sixpence
for thy
leman: hadst it?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I did impeticos thy gratillity; for
Malvolio's nose
is no whipstock: my lady has
a white hand, and the
Myrmidons are no bottle-ale
houses.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Excellent! why, this is the best
fooling, when
all is done. Now, a song.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come on; there is sixpence for
you: let's have
a song.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
There's a testril of me too: if one
knight give a—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Would you have a love-song, or a
song of good
life?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: A love-song, a love-song.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Ay, ay: I care not for good life.

lg.l: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?
O, stay and hear; your true love's coming,
That can sing both high and low:
Trip no further, pretty sweeting;
Journeys end in lovers meeting,
Every wise man's son doth know.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Excellent good, i' faith.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Good, good.

lg.l: What is love? 'tis not hereafter;
Present mirth hath present laughter;
What's to come is still unsure:
In delay there lies no plenty;
Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,
Youth's a stuff will not endure.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: A mellifluous voice, as I am true knight.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: A contagious breath.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Very sweet and contagious, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
To hear by the nose, it is dulcet in
contagion.
But shall we make the welkin dance
indeed? shall we
rouse the night-owl in a
catch that will draw three
souls out of one
weaver? shall we do that?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
An you love me, let's do it: I am
dog at a
catch.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By'r lady, sir, and some dogs will
catch well.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Most certain. Let our catch be,
'Thou knave.'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
'Hold thy peace, thou knave,' knight?
I shall be constrained
in't to call thee knave,
knight.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
'Tis not the first time I have constrained
one to
call me knave. Begin, fool: it
begins 'Hold thy peace.'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: I shall never begin if I hold my peace.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l:
Good, i' faith. Come, begin. [Catch sung.
Enter MARIA.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
What a caterwauling do you keep
here! If
my lady have not called up her steward
Malvolio and
bid him turn you out of
doors, never trust me.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
My lady's a Cataian, we are politicians,
Malvolio's
a Peg-a-Ramsey, and 'Three
merry men be we.' Am not I
consanguineous?
am I not of her blood? Tillyvally. Lady! [Sings.]

lg.l: 'There dwelt a man in Babylon, lady, lady!'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Beshrew me, the knight's in admirable
fooling.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Ay, he does well enough if he be
disposed, and so
do I too: he does it with a
better grace, but I do 't more
natural.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: 'O, the twelfth day of
December,'—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l:
For the love o' God, peace!
Enter MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
My masters, are you mad? or what
are you?
Have you no wit, manners, nor honesty,
but to gabble
like tinkers at this time of
night? Do ye make an alehouse
of my lady's
house, that ye squeak out your coziers'
catches
without any mitigation or remorse of voice?
Is there no respect of place, persons, nor time
in you?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
We did keep time, sir, in our
catches. Sneck up!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Toby, I must be round with you.
My lady
bade me tell you, that, though she
harbors you as her kinsman,
she's nothing
allied to your disorders. If you can
separate
yourself and your misdemeanors, you are welcome
to the house; if not, an it would please
you to take
leave of her, she is very willing to
bid you farewell.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Farewell, dear heart, since I must
needs be gone.'

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, good Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
'His eyes do show his days are almost
done.'

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is't even so?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: 'But I will never die.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Sir Toby, there you lie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This is much credit to you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: 'Shall I bid him go?'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'What an if you do?'

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: 'Shall I bid him go, and spare not?'

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'O no, no, no, no, you dare not.'

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Out o' tune, sir: ye lie. Art any
more than a steward?
Dost thou think, because
thou art virtuous, there
shall be no more
cakes and ale?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Yes, by Saint Anne, and ginger shall
be hot i' the
mouth too.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Thou'rt i' the right. Go, sir, rub
your chain with
crums. A stoup of wine,.
Maria!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Mistress Mary, if you prized my,
lady's favor
at any thing more than contempt,
you would not give
means for this uncivil
rule: she shall know of it, by this
hand. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go shake your ears.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
'Twere as good a deed as to drink
when a man's
a-hungry, to challenge him the
field, and then to break
promise with him and
make a fool of him.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Do't, knight: I'll write thee a challenge:
or I'll
deliver thy indignation to him
by word of mouth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sweet Sir Toby, be patient for tonight:
since
the youth of the count's was today
with my lady, she is
much out of quiet.
For Monsieur Malvolio, let me alone
with
him: if I do not gull him into a nayword,
and make
him a common recreation, do not
think I have wit enough
to lie straight in my
bed: I know I can do it.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Posses us, possess us; tell us
something of him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Marry, sir, sometimes he is a kindof puritan.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
O, if I thought that I'ld beat him
like a dog!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What, for being a puritan? thy exquisite
reason,
dear knight?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
I have no exquisite reason for't,
but I have reason
good enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
The devil a puritan that he is, or any
thing
constantly, but a time-pleaser; an affectioned
ass, that
cons state without book and
utters it by great swarths:
the best persuaded
of himself, so crammed, as he thinks,
with excellencies,
that it is his grounds of faith that
all
that look on him love him; and on that
vice in him will
my revenge find notable cause
to work.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: What wilt thou do?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I will drop in his way some obscure
epistles of
love; wherein, by the colour of his
beard, the shape of his
leg, the manner of his
gait, the expressure of his eye,
forehead, and
complexion, he shall find himself most
feelingly
personated. I can write very like my lady
your niece: on a forgotten matter we can
hardly make
distinction of our hands.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Excellent! I smell a device.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: I have't in my nose too.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
He shall think, by the letters that
thou wilt drop,
that they come from my niece,
and that she's in love
with him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
My purpose is, indeed, a horse of
that color.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
And your horse now would make
him an ass.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ass, I doubt not.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: O, 'twill be admirable!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Sport royal, I warrant you: I know
my physic
will work with him. I will plant you
two, and let
the fool make a third, where he
shall find the letter:
observe his construction
of it. For this night, to bed, and
dream on
the event. Farewell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Good night, Penthesilea.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Before me, she's a good wench.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
She's a beagle, true-bred, and one
that adores me:
what o' that?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: I was adored once too.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Let's to bed, knight. Thou hadst
need send for
more money.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
If I cannot recover your niece, I
am a foul way
out.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Send for money, knight: if thou
hast her not i' the
end, call me cut.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
If I do not, never trust me, take
it how you will.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come, come, I'll go burn some
sack; 'tis too late
to go to bed now; come,
knight; come, knight. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV
div.stage: Enter DUKE, VIOLA, CURIO, and others.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Give me some music. Now, good morrow, friends.
Now, good Cesario, but that piece of song,
That old and antique song we heard last night:
Methought it did relieve my passion much,
More than light airs and recollected terms
Of these most brisk and giddy-paced times:
Come, but one verse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
He is not here, so please your lordship,
that
should sing it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
Feste, the jester, my lord; a fool that
the lady
Olivia's father took much delight in.
He is about the
house.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
Seek him out, and play the tune the while. [Exit Curio.
Music plays.
Come hither, boy: if ever thou shalt love,
In the sweet pangs of it remember me;
For such as I am all true lovers are,
Unstaid and skittish in all motions else,
Save in the constant image of the creature
That is beloved. How dost thou like this tune?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: It gives a very echo to the seat
Where Love is throned.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Thou dcst speak masterly:
My life upon't, young though thou art, thine eye
Hath stay'd upon some favor that it loves:
Hath it not, boy?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: A little, by your favor.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What kind of woman is't?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Of your complexion.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: She is not worth thee, then. What years, i' faith?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: About your years, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Too old, by heaven: let still the woman take
An elder than herself: so wears she to him,
So sways she level in her husband's heart:
For, boy, however we do praise ourselves,
Our fancies are more giddy and unfirm,
More longing, wavering, sooner lost and worn,
Than women's are.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I think it well, my lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Then let thy love be younger than thyself,
Or thy affection cannot hold the bent;
For women are as roses, whose fair flower
Being once display'd, doth fall that very hour.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And so they are: alas, that they are so;

To die, even when they to perfection grow!
Re-enter CURIO and CLOWN.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O, fellow, come, the song we had last night.
Mark it, Cesario, it is old and plain;
The spinsters and the knitters in the sun
And the free maids that weave their thread with bones
Do use to chant it: it is silly sooth,
And dallies with the innocence of love,
Like the old age.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: Are you ready, sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay; prithee, sing. [Music.

lg.l: Come away, come away, death,
And in sad cypress let me be laid;
Fly away, fly away, breath;
I am slain by a fair cruel maid.
My shroud of white, stuck all with yew,
O, prepare it!
My part of death, no one so true

Did share it.
Not a flower, not a flower sweet,
On my black coffin let there be strown;
Not a friend, not a friend greet
My poor corpse, where my bones shall be thrown:
A thousand thousand sighs to save,
Lay me, O, where
Sad true lover never find my grave,
To weep there!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There's for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No pains, sir; I take pleaure in
singing, sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I'll pay thy pleasure then.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l:
Truly, sir, and pleasure will be paid,
one time or
another.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Give me now leave to leave thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now, the melancholy god protect
thee; and the
tailor make thy doublet of
changeable taffeta, for thy
mind is a very opal.
I would have men of such constancy
put to
sea, that their business might be every thing
and their intent every where; for that's it that
always
makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let all the rest give place. [Curio and Attendants retire.
Once more, Cesario,
Get thee to yond same sovereign cruelty:
Tell her, my love, more noble than the world,
Prizes not quantity of dirty lands;
The parts that fortune hath bestow'd upon her,
Tell her, I hold as giddily as fortune;
But 'tis that miracle and queen of gems
That nature pranks her in attracts my soul.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: But if she cannot love you, sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I cannot be so answer'd.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Sooth, but you must.
Say that some lady, as perhaps there is,
Hath for your love as great a pang of heart
As you have for Olivia: you cannot love her;
You tell her so; must she not then be answer'd?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There is no woman's sides
Can bide the beating of so strong a passion
As love doth give my heart; no woman's heart
So big, to hold so much; they lack retention
Alas, their love may be call'd appetite,
No motion of the liver, but the palate,
That suffer surfeit, cloyment and revolt;
But mine is all as hungry as the sea,
And can digest as much: make no compare
Between that love a woman can bear me
And that I owe Olivia.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Ay, but I know—

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What dost thou know?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Too well what love women to men may owe:
In faith, they are as true of heart as we.
My father had a daughter loved a man,
As it might be, perhaps, were I a woman,
I should your lordship.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: And what's her history?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: A blank, my lord. She never told her love,
But let concealment, like a worm i' the bud,
Feed on her damask cheek: she pined in thought,
And with a green and yellow melancholy
She sat like patience on a monument,
Smiling at grief. Was not this love indeed?
We men may say more, swear more: but indeed
Our shows are more than will; for still we prove
Much in our vows, but little in our love.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But died thy sister of her love, my boy?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I am all the daughters of my father's house,
And all the brothers too: and yet I know not.
Sir, shall I to this lady?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Ay, that's the theme.
To her in haste; give her this jewel; say,
My love can give no place, bide no denay. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE V
div.stage: Enter SIR TOBY, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll come: if I lose a scruple of
this sport,
let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Wouldst thou not be glad to have
the niggardly
rascally sheep-biter come by
some notable shame?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I would exult, man: you know, he
brought me out
o' favor with my lady about
a bear-baiting here.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
To anger him we'll have the bear
again; and
we will fool him black and blue:
shall we not, Sir
Andrew?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
An we do not, it is pity of our
lives.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Here comes the little villain. Enter MARIA.
How now, my
metal of India!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get ye all three into the box-tree:
Malvolio's
coming down this walk: he has
been yonder i' the
sun practising behavior to
his own shadow this half
hour: observe him,
for the love of mockery; for I know
this letter
will make a contemplative idiot of him.
Close,
in the name of jesting! Lie thou there
[throws down a letter],for here comes
the
trout that must be caught with tickling. [Exit.
Enter MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Tis but fortune; all is fortune.
Maria once
told me she did affect me: and I
have heard herself come
thus near, that,
should she fancy, it should be one of
my complexion.
Besides, she uses me with a more exalted
respect than any one else that follows
her. What
should I think on't?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Here's an overweening rogue!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
O, peace! Contemplation makes a
rare turkey-cock
of him: how he jets under
his advanced plumes!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Peace, I say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To be Count Malvolio!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Ah, rogue!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Pistol him, pistol him.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Peace, peace!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
There is example for't; the lady of
the Strachy
married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Fie on him, Jezebel!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
O, peace! now he's deeply in: look
how imagination
blows him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Having been three months married to
her,
sitting in my state,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
O, for a stone-bow, to hit him in
the eye!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Calling my officers about me, in
my branched
velvet gown; having come from
a day-bed, where I
have left Olivia sleeping,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Fire and brimstone!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O, peace, peace!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
And then to have the humor of state;
and after
a demure travel of regard, telling
them I know my
place as I would they should
do theirs, to ask for my
kinsman Toby,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Bolts and shackles!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: O peace, peace, peace! now, now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Seven of my people, with an obedient
start,
make out for him: I frown the while;
and perchance
wind up my watch, or play
with my—some rich jewel.
Toby approaches;
courtesies there to me,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Shall this fellow live?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Though our silence be drawn from
us with cars,
yet peace.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I extend my hand to him thus,
quenching my
familiar smile with an austere
regard of control,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
And does not Toby take you a
blow o' the lips
then?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Saying, 'Cousin Toby, my fortunes
having cast
me on your niece give me this
prerogative of speech,'—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: What, what?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'You must amend your drunkenness.'

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Out, scab!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nay, patience, or we break the
sinews of our
plot.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Besides, you waste the treasure of
your time
with a foolish knight,'—

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: That's me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'One Sir Andrew,'—

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
I knew 'twas I; for many do call
me fool.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What employment have we here? [Taking up the letter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
O, peace! and the spirit of humors
intimate reading
aloud to him!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
By my life, this is my lady's hand:
these be her
very C's, her U's and her T's;
and thus makes she her
great P's. It is, in contempt
of question, her hand.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Her C's, her U's and her T's:
why that?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'To the unknown beloved,
this, and my good wishes:'—
her very phrases!
By your leave, wax. Soft! and the impressure
her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal:
'tis my
lady. To whom should this be?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: This wins him, liver and all.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Jove knows I love:
But who?
Lips, do not move;

No man
must know.
sp.p:
'No man must know.' What follows?
the
numbers altered! 'No man must know:'
if
this should be thee, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Marry, hang thee, brock!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I may command where I adore:

But silence, like a Lucrece
knife,
With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore:

M, O, A, I, doth
sway my life.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: A fustian riddle!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Excellent wench, say I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'M, O, A, I, doth sway my life.'Nay,
but first,
let me see, let me see, let me see.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
What dish o' poison has she dressed
him!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
And with what wing the staniel
checks at it!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'I may command where I adore.'
Why, she may
command me: I serve her;
she is my lady. Why, this is
evident to any
formal capacity; there is no obstruction
in
this: and the end,—what should that alphabetical
position
portend? If I could make that
resemble something
in me,—Softly! M, O, A,
I,—

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
O, ay, make up that: he is now
at a cold scent.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Sowter will cry upon't for all this,
though it be
as rank as a fox.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M,—Malvolio; M,—why, that begins
my name.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Did not I say he would work it out?
the cur
is excellent at faults.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M,—but then there is no consonancy
in the sequel;
that suffers under probation:
A should follow, but O
does.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: And O shall end, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Ay, or I'll cudgel him, and make
him cry O!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And then I comes behind.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Ay, an you had any eye behind you,
you might
see more detraction at your heels
than fortunes before
you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
M, O, A, I; this simulation is not
as the former:
and yet, to crush this a little,
it would bow to me, for every
one of these
letters are in my name. Soft! here follows
prose. [Reads]
'If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In
my stars
I am above thee; but be not afraid
of greatness: some
are born great, some
achieve greatness, and some
have greatnes
thrust upon 'em. Thy Fates open their
hands;
let thy blood and spirit embrace them; and,
to inure
thyself to what thou art like to be,
cast thy humble
slough and appear fresh. Be
opposite with a kinsman,
surly with servants;
let thy tongue tang arguments of
state; put
thyself into the trick of singularity: she
thus
advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember
who
commended thy yellow stockings, and
wished to see thee
ever cross-gartered: I say,
remember. Go to, thou art
made, if thou desirest
to be so; if not, let me see thee a
steward
still, the fellow of servants, and not
worthy to
touch Fortune's fingers. Farewell.
She that would alter
service with thee.
THE FORTUNATE-UNHAPPY.'
Daylight and
champain discovers not more:
this is open. I will be
proud, I will read politic
authors, I will baffle Sir
Toby, I will wash off
gross acquaintance, I will be point-devise
the
very man. I do not now fool myself, to let
imagination jade me; for every reason excites
to this,
that my lady loves me. She did commend
my yellow
stockings of late, she did
praise my leg being cross-gartered;
and in this
she manifests herself to my love, and
with a
kind of injunction drives me to these habits of
her liking. I thank my stars I am happy. I
will be
strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and
cross-gartered,
even with the swiftness of putting
on. Jove and my
stars be praised! Here
is yet a postscript. [Reads]
'Thou canst
not choose but know who
I am. If thou entertainest my love, let
it appear
in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee
well; therefore
in my presence still smile, dear
my sweet, I prithee.'
Jove,
I thank thee: I will smile; I will do
everything that thou
wilt have me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I will not give my part of this sport
for a pension
of thousands to be paid from the
Sophy.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I could marry this wench for this
device.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: So could I too.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
And ask no other dowry with her
but such another
jest.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Nor I neither.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Here comes my noble gull-catcher. Re-enter MARIA.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Or o' mine either?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Shall I play my freedom at tray-
trip, and become
thy bond-slave?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: I' faith, or I either?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Why, thou hast put him in such a
dream, that
when the image of it leaves him
he must run mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, but say true; does it work
upon him?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Like aqua-vitae with a midwife.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If you will then see the fruits of the
sport, mark
his first approach before my lady:
he will come to her
in yellow stockings, and
'tis a color she abhors, and
cross-gartered, a
fashion she detests; and he will smile
upon
her, which will now be so unsuitable to her
disposition,
being addicted to a melancholy as
she is, that it
cannot but turn him into a notable
contempt. If you will
see it, follow me.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
To the gates of Tartar, thou most
excellent devil
of wit!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: I'll make one too. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Enter VIOLA, and CLOWN with a tabor.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Save thee, friend, and thy music:
dost thou live
by thy tabor?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: No, sir, I live by the church.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Art thou a churchman?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No such matter, sir: I do live by the
church; for
I do live at my house, and my
house doth stand by the
church.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
So thou mayst say, the king lies by a
beggar, if a
beggar dwell near him; or, the
church stands by thy tabor,
if thy tabor stand
by the church.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You have said, sir. To see this age!
A sentence is
but a cheveril glove to a good
wit: how quickly the
wrong side may be
turned outward!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Nay, that's certain; they that dally
nicely with
words may quickly make them
wanton.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would, therefore, my sister had had
no name, sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why, man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, sir, her name's a word; and to
dally with
that word might make my sister
wanton. But indeed
words are very rascals
since bonds disgraced them.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Thy reason, man?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Troth, sir, I can yield you none without
words;
and words are grown so false, I
am loath to prove reason
with them.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I warrant thou art a merry fellow
and carest for
nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Not so, sir, I do care for something;
but in my conscience,
sir, I do not care for
you: if that be to care for nothing,
sir, I
would it would make you invisible.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Art not thou the Lady Olivia's fool?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No, indeed, sir; the Lady Olivia has
no folly: she
will keep no fool, sir, till she be
married; and fools are
as like husbands as
pilchards are to herrings; the husband's
the
bigger: I am indeed not her fool, but her corrupter
of words.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Foolery, sir, does walk about the orb
like the
sun, it shines every where. I would
be sorry, sir, but the
fool should be as oft with
your master as with my mistress:
I think I
saw your wisdom there.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Nay, an thou pass upon me, I'll no
more with
thee. Hold, there's expenses for
thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Now Jove, in his next commodity of
hair, send
thee a beard!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
By my troth, I'll tell thee, I am almost
sick for
one; [Aside] though I would not have
it grow on my chin. Is
thy lady within?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Would not a pair of these have bred, sir?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Yes, being kept together and put to use.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I would play Lord Pandarus of
Phrygia, sir, to bring
a Cressida to this
Troilus.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I understand you, sir; 'tis well begged.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
The matter, I hope, is not great, sir,
begging but a
beggar: Cressida was a beggar.
My lady is within, sir. I will
construe to them
whence you come; who you are and
what you
would are out of my welkin, I might say 'element,'
but the word is over-worn. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: This fellow is wise enough to play the fool;
And to do that well craves a kind of wit:
He must observe their mood on whom he jests,
The quality of persons, and the time,
And, like the haggard, check at every feather
That comes before his eye. This is a practice
As full of labor as a wise man's art:
For folly that he wisely shows is fit;

But wise men, folly-fall'n, quite taint their wit.
Enter SIR TOBY and SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: Save you, gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Dieu vous garde, monsieur.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Et vous aussi; votre serviteur.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
I hope, sir, you are; and I am
yours.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Will you encounter the house? my
niece is desirous
you should enter, if your
trade be to her.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I am bound to your niece, sir; I
mean, she is the
list of my voyage.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Taste your legs, sir; put them to
motion.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
My legs do better understand me, sir,
than I understand
what you mean by bidding
me taste my legs.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I mean, to go, sir, to enter.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I will answer you with gait and entrance.
But we
are prevented.
Enter OLIVIA and MARIA.
Most excellent accomplished lady, the heavens
rain odors
on you!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
That youth's a rare courtier:
'Rain odors;' well.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
My matter hath no voice, lady, but
to your own
most pregnant and vouchsafed ear.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
'Odors,' 'pregnant' and 'vouchsafed:'
I'll get 'em
all three all ready.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Let the garden door be shut, and leave
me to
my hearing. [Exeunt Sir Toby, Sir
Andrew, and Maria.] Give me your hand, sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My duty, madam, and most humble service.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What is your name?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Cesario is your servant's name, fair princess.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: My servant, sir! 'Twas never merry world
Since lowly feigning was call'd compliment:
You're servant to the Count Orsino, youth.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours:
Your servant's servant is your servant, madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: For him, I think not on him: for his thoughts,
Would they were blanks, rather than fill'd with me!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts
On his behalf.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: O, by your leave, I pray you,
I bade you never speak again of him:
But, would you undertake another suit,
I had rather hear you to solicit that
Than music from the spheres.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Dear lady,—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Give me leave, beseech you. I did send,
After the last enchantment you did here,
A ring in chase of you: so did I abuse
Myself, my servant and, I fear me, you:
Under your hard construction must I sit,
To force that on you, in a shameful cunning,
Which you knew none of yours: what might you think?
Have you not set mine honor at the stake
And baited it with all the unmuzzled thoughts
That tyrannous heart can think? To one of your receiving
Enough is shown: a cypress, not a bosom,
Hideth my heart. So, let me hear you speak.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I pity you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: That's a degree to love.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No, not a grize; for 'tis a vulgar proof,
That very oft we pity enemies.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why, then, methinks 'tis time to smile again.
O world, how apt the poor are to be proud!
If one should be a prey, how much the better

To fall before the lion than the wolf!
Clock strikes.
The clock upbraids me with the waste of time.
Be not afraid, good youth, I will not have you:
And yet, when wit and youth is come to harvest,
Your wife is like to reap a proper man:
There lies your way, due west.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l:
Then westward-ho!
Grace and good disposition
Attend your ladyship!
You'll nothing, madam, to my lord by me?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Stay:
I prithee, tell me what thou think'st of me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: That you do think you are not what you are.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: If I think so, I think the same of you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then think you right: I am not what I am.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I would you were as I would have you be!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Would it be better, madam, than I am?
I wish it might, for now I am your fool.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: O, what a deal of scorn looks beautiful
In the contempt and anger of his lip!
A murderous guilt shows not itself more soon
Than love that would seem hid: love's night is noon.
Cesario, by the roses of the spring,
By maidhood, honor, truth and every thing,
I love thee so, that, maugre all thy pride,
Nor wit nor reason can my passion hide.
Do not extort thy reasons from this clause,
For that I woo, thou therefore hast no cause,
But rather reason thus with reason fetter,
Love sought is good, but given unsought is better.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: By innocence I swear, and by my youth,
I have one heart, one bosom and one truth,
And that no woman has; nor never none
Shall mistress be of it, save I alone.
And so adieu, good madam: never more
Will I my master's tears to you deplore.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Yet come again; for thou perhaps mayst move
That heart, which now abhors, to like his love. [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I
div.stage: Enter SIR TOBY, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
No, faith, I'll not stay a jot
longer.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Thy reason, dear venom, give thy
reason.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
You must needs yield your reason,
Sir
Andrew.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Marry, I saw your niece do more
favors to the
count's serving-man than ever
she bestowed upon me;
I saw't i' the orchard.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Did she see thee the while, old
boy? tell me that.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: As plain as I see you now.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This was a great argument of love in
her toward
you.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
'Slight, will you make an ass o'
me?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I will prove it legitimate, sir, upon
the oaths of
judgement and reason.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
And they have been grand-jurymen
since before
Noah was a sailor.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
She did show favor to the youth in
your sight
only to exasperate you, to awake
your dormouse valor,
to put fire in your
heart, and brimstone in your liver.
You should
then have accosted her; and with some excellent
jests, fire-new from the mint, you should
have banged
the youth into dumbness. This
was looked for at your
hand, and this was
balked: the double gilt of this opportunity
you let time wash off, and you are now sailed
into
the north of my lady's opinion; where
you will hang
like an icicle on a Dutchman's
beard, unless you do redeem
it by some
laudable attempt either of valor or
policy.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
An't be any way, it must be with
valor; for
policy I hate: I had as lief be a
Brownist as a
politician.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Why, then, build me thy fortunes
upon the basis of
valor. Challenge me the
count's youth to fight with him;
hurt him in
eleven places: my niece shall take note of it;
and assure thyself, there is no love-broker in
the world
can more prevail in man's commendation
with woman
than report of valor.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: There is no way but this, Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Will either of you bear me a
challenge to him?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Go, write it in a martial hand; be
curst and brief;
it is no matter how witty, so
it be eloquent and full of
invention: taunt
him with the license of ink: if
thou thou'st
him some thrice, it shall not be amiss; and
as many
lies as will lie in thy sheet of paper,
although the
sheet were big enough for the
bed of Ware in England,
set 'em down: go,
about it. Let there be gall enough
in thy ink,
though thou write with a goose-pen,
no
matter: about it.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: Where shall I find you?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
We'll call thee at the cubiculo: go.
[Exit Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: This is a dear manakin to you, Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I have been dear to him, lad, some
two thousand
strong, or so.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
We shall have a rare letter from him:
but you'll
not deliver't?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Never trust me, then; and by all
means stir on
the youth to an answer. I think
oxen and wainropes
cannot hale them together.
For Andrew, if he were opened,
and
you find so much blood in his liver as will clog
the
foot of a flea, I'll eat the rest of the
anatomy.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
And his opposite, the youth, bears in
his visage no
great presage of cruelty.
Enter MARIA.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Look, where the youngest wren of
nine comes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
If you desire the spleen, and will
laugh yourselves
into stitches, follow me. Yond
gull Malvolio is turned
heathen, a very renegado;
for there is no Christian,
that means to
be saved by believing rightly, can ever
believe
such impossible passages of grossness. He's
in
yellow stockings.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.l: And cross-gartered?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Most villanously; like a pedant that
keeps a
school i' the church. I have dogged
him, like his murderer.
He does obey every
point of the letter that I dropped
to betray
him: he does smile his face into more lines
than is in the new map with the augmentation
of the
Indies: you have not seen such a
thing as 'tis. I can hardly
forbear hurling
things at him. I know my lady will
strike him:
if she do, he'll smile and take't for a great
favor.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come, bring us, bring us where he is.
[Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I would not by my will have troubled you;
But, since you make your pleasure of your pains,
I will no further chide you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I could not stay behind you: my desire,
More sharp than filed steel, did spur me forth;
And not all love to see you, though so much
As might have drawn one to a longer voyage,
But jealousy what might befall your travel,
Being skilless in these parts; which to a stranger,
Unguided and unfriended, often prove
Rough and unhospitable: my willing love,
The rather by these arguments of fear,
Set forth in your pursuit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: My kind Antonio,
I can no other answer make but thanks,
And thanks; and ever . . . oft good turns
Are shuffled off with such uncurrent pay:
But, were my worth as is my conscience firm,
You should find better dealing. What's to do ?
Shall we go see the reliques of this town?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To-morrow, sir: best first go see your lodging.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I am not weary, and 'tis long to night:
I pray you, let us satisfy our eyes
With the memorials and the things of fame
That do renown this city.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would you'ld pardon me;
I do not without danger walk these streets:
Once, in a sea-fight, 'gainst the count his galleys
I did some service; of such note indeed,
That were I ta'en here it would scarce be answer'd.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Belike you slew great number of his people.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The offence is not of such a bloody nature;
Albeit the quality of the time and quarrel
Might well have given us bloody argument.
It might have since been answer'd in repaying
What we took from them; which, for traffic's sake,
Most of our city did: only myself stood out;
For which, if I be lapsed in this place,
I shall pay dear.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do not then walk too open.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It doth not fit me. Hold, sir, here's my purse.
In the south suburbs, at the Elephant,
Is best to lodge: I will bespeak our diet,
Whiles you beguile the time and feed your knowledge
With viewing of the town: there shall you have me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why I your purse?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Haply your eye shall light upon some toy
You have desire to purchase; and your store,
I think, is not for idle markets, sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll be your purse-bearer and leave you
For an hour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To the Elephant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I do remember. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I have sent after him: he says he'll come;
How shall I feast him? what bestow of him?
For youth is bought more oft than begg'd or borrow'd.
I speak too loud.
Where is Malvolio? he is sad and civil,
And suits well for a servant with my fortunes:
Where is Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He's coming, madam;
but in very
strange manner. He is, sure, possessed,
madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter? does he rave?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No, madam, he does nothing but
smile: your ladyship
were best to have some
guard about you, if he
come; for, sure, the
man is tainted in's wits.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l:
Go call him hither.
[Exit Maria.]
I am as mad as he,
If sad and merry madness equal be. Re-enter MARIA, with MALVOLIO.
How now, Malvolio!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sweet lady, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Smilest thou?
I sent for thee upon a sad occasion.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sad, lady! I could be sad:
this does
make some obstruction in the blood,
this cross-gartering;
but what of that?
if it please the
eye of one, it is with me as the very true
sonnet
is, 'Please one, and please all.'

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Why, how dost thou, man?
what is
the matter with thee?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Not black in my mind, though yellow
in my
legs. It did come to his hands, and commands
shall
be executed: I think we do know
the sweet Roman
hand.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Wilt thou go to bed, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
To bed! ay, sweet-heart, and I'll
come to thee.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
God comfort thee! Why dost thou
smile so and
kiss thy hand so oft?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How do you, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
At your request!
yes; nightingales
answer daws.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Why appear you with this ridiculous
boldness
before my lady?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Be not afraid of greatness:' 'twas
well writ.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What meanest thou by that, Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Some are born great,'—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'Some achieve greatness,'—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'And some have greatness thrust
upon them.'

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Heaven restore thee!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Remember who commended thy yellow
stockings,'—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Thy yellow stockings!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'And wished to see thee crossgartered.'

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Cross-gartered!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
'Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest
to be so;'—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Am I made?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: 'If not, let me see thee a servant still.'

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Why, this is very midsummer madness.
Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Madam, the young gentleman of the
Count
Orsino's is returned: I could hardly
entreat him back: he
attends your ladyship's
pleasure.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
I'll come to him. [Exit Servant.]
Good
Maria, let this fellow be looked to. Where's my
cousin Toby? Let some of my people have a
special care
of him: I would not have him
miscarry for the half of
my dowry. [Exeunt Olivia and Maria.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
O, ho! do you come near me now?
no worse
man than Sir Toby to look to me!
This concurs directly
with the letter: she sends
him on purpose, that I may
appear stubborn
to him; for she incites me to that in
the letter.
'Cast thy humble slough,' says she: 'be opposite
with a kinsman, surly with servants; let
thy tongue
tang with arguments of state; put
thyself into the
trick of singularity;' and consequently
sets down the
manner how; as, a sad
face, a reverend carriage, a slow
tongue, in
the habit of some sir of note, and so forth.
I
have limed her; but it is Jove's doing, and
Jove make me
thankful! And when she went
away now, 'Let this fellow
be looked to:'
fellow! not Malvolio, nor after my
degree,
but fellow. Why, every thing adheres together,
that no dram of a scruple, no scruple of a
scruple, no
obstacle, no incredulous or unsafe
circumstance—What
can be said? Nothing
that can be can come between
me and the full
prospect of my hopes. Well, Jove, not I,
is the
doer of this, and he is to be thanked.
Re-enter MARIA, with SIR TOBY and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Which way is he, in the name of
sanctity? If all
the devils of hell be drawn in
little, and Legion himself
possessed him, yet
I'll speak to him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Here he is, here he is. How is't with
you, sir?
how is't with you, man?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Go off; I discard you: let me enjoy
my private:
go off.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Lo, how hollow the fiend speaks
within him!
did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my
lady prays you to have
a care of him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ah, ha! does she so?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Go to, go to; peace, peace; we
must deal
