gently with him: let me alone. How
do you, Malvolio?
how is't with you? What,
man! defy the devil: consider,
he's an enemy
to mankind.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Do you know what you say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
La you, an you speak ill of the devil,
how
he takes it at heart! Pray God, he be not
bewitched!

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Carry his water to the wise woman.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Marry, and it shall be done to-morrow
morning,
if I live. My lady would not lose
him for more than I'll
say.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: How now, mistress!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Prithee, hold thy peace; this is not
the way: do
you not see you move him? let
me alone with him.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
No way but gentleness; gently, gently:
the fiend
is rough, and will not be roughly
used.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Why, how now, my bawcock! how
dost thou, chuck?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Ay, Biddy, come with me. What,
man! 'tis not for
gravity to play at cherry-pit
with Satan: hang him, foul
collier!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Get him to say his prayers, good Sir
Toby, get
him to pray.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: My prayers, minx!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
No, I warrant you, he will not hear
of
godliness.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Go, hang yourselves all! you are idle
shallow
things: I am not of your element:
you shall know more
hereafter. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
If this were played upon a stage now,
I could condemn
it as an improbable fiction.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
His very genius hath taken the infection
of the
device, man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, pursue him now, lest the device
take air
and taint.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why, we shall make him mad indeed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The house will be the quieter.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come, we'll have him in a dark
room and bound.
My niece is already in the
belief that he's mad: we may
carry it thus,
for our pleasure and his penance, till our very
pastime, tired out of breath, prompt us to
have mercy
on him: at which time we will
bring the device to the bar
and crown thee for
a finder of madmen. But see, but see.
Enter SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: More matter for a May morning.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Here's the challenge, read it: I
warrant there's
vinegar and pepper in't.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Is't so saucy?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Ay, is't, I warrant him: do but
read.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Give me. [Reads]
'Youth, whatsoever
thou art, thou art but a scurvy fellow.'

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Good, and valiant.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Wonder not, nor admire
not in thy mind, why I do call
thee so, for I
will show thee no reason for't.'

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
A good note; that keeps you from
the blow of the law.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Thou comest to the lady
Olivia, and in my sight she uses
thee kindly:
but thou liest in thy throat; that is not the
matter
I challenge thee for.'

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Very brief, and to exceeding good
sense—less.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'I will waylay thee going
home; where if it be thy chance
to kill me,'—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Thou killest me like a
rogue and a villain.'

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Still you keep o' the windy side of the
law: good.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
'Fare thee well; and God
have mercy upon one of our
souls! He may
have mercy upon mine; but my hope is better,
and so look to thyself. Thy friend, as thou
usest him, and thy
sworn enemy,
ANDREW AGUECHEEK.
If this letter move him not, his legs cannot:
I'll give't him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
You may have very fit occasion
for't: he is now
in some commerce with my
lady, and will by and by
depart.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Go, Sir Andrew: scout me for him
at the corner
of the orchard like a bum-baily:
so soon as ever thou
seest him, draw; and, as
thou drawest, swear horrible; for
it comes to
pass oft that a terrible oath, with a swaggering
accent sharply twanged off, gives manhood
more
approbation than ever proof itself would
have earned
him. Away!

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.l: Nay, let me alone for swearing. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Now will not I deliver his letter:
for the behavior
of the young gentleman gives
him out to be of good
capacity and breeding;
his employment between his
lord and my niece
confirms no less: therefore this
letter, being
so excellently ignorant, will breed no terror
in
the youth: he will find it comes from a coldpole.
But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by
word of mouth;
set upon Aguecheek a notable
report of valor; and drive
the gentleman, as
I know his youth will aptly receive it,
into a
most hideous opinion of his rage, skill, fury
and
impetuosity. This will so fright them both
that they will
kill one another by the look, like
cockatrices.
Re-enter OLIVIA, with VIOLA.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Here he comes with your niece: give
them way
till he take leave, and presently after
him.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I will meditate the while upon
some horrid message
for a challenge. [Exeunt Sir Toby, Fabian, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: I have said too much unto a heart of stone
And laid mine honor too unchary out:
There's something in me that reproves my fault;
But such a headstrong potent fault it is,
That it but mocks reproof.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: With the same 'havior that your passion bears
Goes on my master's grief.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Here, wear this jewel for me, 'tis my picture;
Refuse it not; it hath no tongue to vex you;
And I beseech you come again to-morrow.
What shall you ask of me that I'll deny,
That honor saved may upon asking give?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Nothing but this; your true love for my master.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: How with mine honor may I give him that
Which I have given to you?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I will acquit you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Well, come again to-morrow: fare thee well:

A fiend like thee might bear my soul to hell. [Exit.
Re-enter SIR TOBY and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Gentleman, God save thee.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And you, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
That defence thou hast, betake thee
to't: of what
nature the wrongs are thou hast
done him, I know not;
but thy intercepter, full
of despite, bloody as the hunter,
attends thee
at the orchard-end: dismount thy tuck,
be
yare in thy preparation, for thy assailant is
quick, skilful
and deadly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
You mistake, sir; I am sure no man
hath any quarrel
to me: my remembrance is
very free and clear from
any image of offence
done to any man.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
You'll find it otherwise, I assure
you: therefore, if
you hold your life at any
price, betake you to your guard;
for your opposite
hath in him what youth, strength, skill
and wrath can furnish man withal.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I pray you, sir, what is he?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
He is knight, dubbed with unhatched
rapier and
on carpet consideration;
but he is a devil in private brawl:
souls and
bodies hath he divorced three; and his incensement
at this moment is so implacable,
that satisfaction
can be none but by pangs of
death and sepulchre. Hob,
nob, is his word;
give't or take't.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I will return again into the house and
desire
some conduct of the lady. I am no
fighter. I have heard
of some kind of men that
put quarrels purposely on others,
to taste their
valor: belike this is a man of that
quirk.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Sir, no; his indignation derives itself
out of a very
competent injury: therefore,
get you on and give him
his desire. Back
you shall not to the house, unless you
undertake
that with me which with as much safety
you
might answer him: therefore, on, or strip
your sword
stark naked; for meddle you must,
that's certain, or forswear
to wear iron about
you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
This is as uncivil as strange. I beseech
you, do
me this courteous office, as to
know of the knight what
my offence to him
is: it is something of my negligence,
nothing
of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I will do so. Signior Fabian, stay
you by this
gentleman till my return. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Pray you, sir, do you know of this matter?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
I know the knight is incensed against
you, even to
a mortal arbitrement; but nothing
of the circumstance
more.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I beseech you, what manner of man is he?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Nothing of that wonderful promise,
to read him
by his form, as you are like to find
him in the proof of
his valor. He is, indeed,
sir, the most skilful, bloody and
fatal opposite
that you could possibly have found in any
part
of Illyria. Will you walk towards him? I will
make
your peace with him if I can.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
I shall be much bound to you for 't:
I am one
that had rather go with sir priest
than sir knight: I care
not who knows so
much of my mettle. [Exeunt.
Re-enter SIR TOBY, with SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Why, man, he's a very devil; I
have not seen such
a firago. I had a pass with
him, rapier, scabbard and all,
and he gives me
the stuck in with such a mortal motion,
that it
is inevitable; and on the answer, he pays you
as
surely as your feet hit the ground they step
on. They
say he has been fencer to the Sophy.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: Pox on't, I'll not meddle with him.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Ay, but he will not now be pacified:
Fabian can scarce hold him yonder.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Plague on 't, an I thought he had
been valiant
and so cunning in fence, I'ld have
seen him damned ere
I'ld have challenged him.
Let him let the matter slip, and
I'll give him
my horse, grey Capilet.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I'll make the motion: stand here,
make a good
show on't: this shall end without
the perdition of souls. [Aside]
Marry, I'll
ride your horse as well as I ride you.
Re-enter FABIAN and VIOLA. [To Fab.]
I have his horse to take up the
quarrel: I have persuaded
him the youth's a
devil.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
He is as horribly conceited of him;
and pants and
looks pale, as if a bear were at
his heels.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
There's no remedy, sir;
he will fight with you for's
oath sake: marry,
he hath better bethought him of his
quarrel,
and he finds that now scarce to be worth talking
of: therefore draw, for the supportance of
his vow;
he protests he will not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p:
Pray God defend me! A little
thing would make
me tell them how much
I lack of a man.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Give ground, if you see him furious.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come, Sir Andrew, there's no remedy;
the gentleman
will, for his honor's sake,
have one bout with you;
he cannot by the
duello avoid it: but he has promised
me, as
he is a gentleman and a soldier, he will not
hurt
you. Come on; to't.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: Pray God, he keep his oath!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I do assure you, 'tis against my will. [They draw. Enter ANTONIO.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Put up your sword. If this young gentleman
Have done offence, I take the fault on me:
If you offend him, I for him defy you.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: You, sir! why, what are you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: One, sir, that for his love dares yet do more
Than you have heard him brag to you he will.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Nay, if you be an undertaker, I am
for you. [They draw.
Enter Officers.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
O good Sir Toby, hold! here come
the officers.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: I'll be with you anon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Pray, sir, put your sword up, if you please.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Marry, will I, sir; and, for that
I promised you, I'll
be as good as my word:
he will bear you easily and
reins well.

sp.speaker: First Off.
sp.p: This is the man; do thy office.

sp.speaker: Sec. Off.
sp.p:
Antonio, I arrest thee at the suit
of Count Orsino.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You do mistake me, sir.

sp.speaker: First Off.
sp.l: No, sir, no jot; I know your favor well,
Though now you have no sea-cap on your head.
Take him away: he knows I know him well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must obey. [To Vio.] This comes with seeking you:
But there's no remedy; I shall answer it.
What will you do, now my necessity
Makes me to ask you for my purse? It grieves me
Much more for what I cannot do for you
Than what befalls myself. You stand amazed;
But be of comfort.

sp.speaker: Sec. Off.
sp.l: Come, sir, away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must entreat of you some of that money.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: What money, sir?
For the fair kindness you have show'd me here,
And, part, being prompted by your present trouble,
Out of my lean and low ability
I'll lend you something: my having is not much;
I'll make division of my present with you:
Hold, there's half my coffer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will you deny me now?
Is't possible that my deserts to you
Can lack persuasion? Do not tempt my misery,
Lest that it make me so unsound a man
As to upbraid you with those kindnesses
That I have done for you.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I know of none;
Nor know I you by voice or any feature:
I hate ingratitude more in a man
Than lying, vainness, babbling, drunkenness,
Or any taint of vice whose strong corruption
Inhabits our frail blood.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O heavens themselves!

sp.speaker: Sec. Off.
sp.l: Come, sir, I pray you, go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let me speak a little. This youth that you see here
I snatch'd one half out of the jaws of death,
Relieved him with such sanctity of love,
And to his image, which methought did promise
Most venerable worth, did I devotion.

sp.speaker: First Off.
sp.l: What's that to us? The time goes by: away!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But O how vile an idol proves this god
Thou hast, Sebastian, done good feature shame.
In nature there's no blemish but the mind;
None can be call'd deform'd but the unkind:
Virtue is beauty, but the beauteous evil
Are empty trunks o'erflourish'd by the devil.

sp.speaker: First Off.
sp.l:
The man grows mad: away with him!
Come, come, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lead me on. [Exit with Officers.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Methinks his words do from such passion fly,
That he believes himself: so do not I.
Prove true, imagination, O, prove true,
That I, dear brother, be now ta'en for you!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come hither, knight; come hither,
Fabian: we'll
whisper o'er a couplet or two of
most sage saws.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: He named Sebastian: I my brother know
Yet living in my glass; even such and so
In favor was my brother, and he went
Still in this fashion, color, ornament,
For him I imitate: O, if it prove,
Tempests are kind and salt waves fresh in love. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
A very dishonest paltry boy, and
more a coward
than a hare: his dishonesty
appears in leaving his friend
here in necessity
and denying him; and for his cowardship,
ask
Fabian.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
A coward, a most devout coward, religious
in
it.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: 'Slid, I'll after him again and beat him.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Do; cuff him soundly, but never
draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p: An I do not,—[Exit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Come, let's see the event.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
I dare lay any money 'twill be
nothing yet. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Will you make me believe that I am
not sent for
you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Go to, go to, thou art a foolish fellow:
Let me be clear of thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well held out, i' faith! No, I do not
know you;
nor I am not sent to you by my
lady, to bid you come
speak with her; nor
your name is not Master Cesario;
nor this is
not my nose neither. Nothing that is so is so.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I prithee, vent thy folly somewhere else:

Thou
know'st not me.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Vent my folly; he has heard that
word of some
great man and now applies it to
a fool. Vent my folly!
I am afraid this great
lubber, the world, will prove a
cockney. I
prithee now, ungird thy strangeness and tell
me what I shall vent to my lady: shall I vent
to her that
thou art coming?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I prithee, foolish Greek, depart from me:

There's
money for thee: if you tarry longer,
I shall give worse
payment.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth, thou hast an open hand.
These wise men
that give fools money get
themselves a good report—
after fourteen years'
purchase.
Enter SIR ANDREW, SIR TOBY, and FABIAN.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Now, sir, have I met you again?
there's for you.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why, there's for thee, and there, and there.
Are all the people mad?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Hold, sir, or I'll throw your dagger
o'er the house.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
This will I tell my lady straight: I
would not be
in some of your coats for two
pence. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Come on, sir; hold.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
Nay, let him alone: I'll go another
way to work
with him; I'll have an action
of battery against him, if
there be any law
in Illyria: though I struck him first, yet
it's
no matter for that.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.p: Let go thy hand.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Come, sir, I will not let you go.
Come, my young
soldier, put up your iron:
you are well fleshed; come
on.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I will be free from thee. What wouldst thou now?
If thou darest tempt me further, draw thy sword.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
What, what? Nay, then I must
have an ounce or
two of this malapert blood
from you.
Enter OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Hold, Toby; on thy life I charge thee, hold!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Will it be ever thus? Ungracious wretch,
Fit for the mountains and the barbarous caves,
Where manners ne'er were preach'd! out of my sight!
Be not offended, dear Cesario.
Rudesby, be gone! [Exeunt Sir Toby, Sir Andrew, and Fabian.
I prithee, gentle friend,
Let thy fair wisdom, not thy passion, sway
In this uncivil and unjust extent
Against thy peace. Go with me to my house,
And hear thou there how many fruitless pranks
This ruffian hath botch'd up, that thou thereby
Mayst smile at this: thou shalt not choose but go:
Do not deny. Beshrew his soul for me,
He started one poor heart of mine in thee.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What relish is in this? how runs the stream?
Or I am mad, or else this is a dream:
Let fancy still my sense in Lethe steep;
If it be thus to dream, still let me sleep!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Nay, come, I prithee; would thou'ldst be ruled by me!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Madam, I will.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: O, say so, and so be! [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Nay, I prithee, put on this gown and
this beard;
make him believe thou art Sir
Topas the curate: do it
quickly; I'll call Sir
Toby the whilst. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Well, I'll put it on, and I will dissemble
myself
in't; and I would I were the first
that ever dissembled
in such a gown. I am not
tall enough to become the
function well, nor
lean enough to be thought a good
student; but
to be said an honest man and a good housekeeper
goes as fairly as to say a careful man
and a great
scholar. The competitors enter.
Enter SIR TOBY and MARIA.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Jove bless thee, master Parson.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Bonos dies, Sir Toby: for, as the old
hermit of Prague,
that never saw pen and ink,
very wittily said to a niece
of King Gorboduc,
'That that is is;' so I, being Master Parson,
am master Parson; for, what is 'that' but
'that,' and 'is' but 'is'?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: To him, Sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What, ho, I say! peace in this prison!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: The knave counterfeits well; a good knave.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Who calls there?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Sir Topas the curate, who comes to
visit Malvolio
the lunatic.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Topas, Sir Topas, good Sir Topas,
go to my
lady.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Out, hyperbolical fiend! how vexest
thou this
man! talkest thou nothing but of
ladies?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: Well said, master Parson.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Sir Topas, never was man thus
wronged: good
Sir Topas, do not think I am
mad: they have laid me
here in hideous darkness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Fie, thou dishonest Satan! I call thee
by the
most modest terms; for I am one of
those gentle ones
that will use the devil himself
with courtesy: sayest thou
that house is dark?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: As hell, Sir Topas.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, it hath bay windows transparent
as barricadoes,
and the clearstores toward the
south north are
as lustrous as ebony; and yet
complainest thou of
obstruction?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I am not mad, Sir Topas: I say to
you, this house is
dark.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Madman, thou errest: I say, there is
no darkness
but ignorance; in which thou art
more puzzled than the
Egyptians in their fog.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I say, this house is as dark as ignorance,
though
ignorance were as dark as hell;
and I say, there was never
man thus abused.
I am no more mad than you are:
make the
trial of it in any constant question.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
What is the opinion of Pythagoras
concerning
wild fowl?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
That the soul of our grandam might
happily
inhabit a bird.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: What thinkest thou of his opinion?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
I think nobly of the soul, and no way
approve
his opinion.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Fare thee well. Remain thou still in
darkness:
thou shalt hold the opinion of Pythagoras
ere I will allow
of thy wits, and fear
to kill a woodcock, lest thou dispossess
the
soul of thy grandam. Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir Topas, Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p: My most exquisite Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay, I am for all waters.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Thou mightest have done this without
thy beard
and gown: he sees thee not.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
To him in thine own voice, and
bring me word
how thou findest him: I would
we were well rid of this
knavery. If he may
be conveniently delivered, I would
he were, for
I am now so far in offence with my niece
that
I cannot pursue with any safety this sport to
the upshot.
Come by and by to my chamber. [Exeunt Sir Toby and Maria.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.l: 'Hey, Robin, jolly Robin,

Tell me how my lady
does.'

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Fool!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: 'My lady is unkind, perdy.'

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Fool!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: 'Alas, why is she so?'

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Fool, I say!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: 'She loves another'—Who calls, ha?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Good fool, as ever thou wilt deserve
well at
my hand, help me to a candle, and pen,
ink and paper:
as I am a gentleman, I will
live to be thankful to thee
for't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Master Malvolio?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Ay, good fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Alas, sir, how fell you besides your
five wits?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Fool, there was never man so notoriously
abused:
I am as well in my wits, fool,
as thou art.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But as well? then you are mad indeed,
if you be
no better in your wits than a fool.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
They have here propertied me; keep
me in
darkness, send ministers to me, asses,
and do all they
can to face me out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Advise you what you say; the minister
is here.
Malvolio, Malvolio, thy wits the
heavens restore! endeavour
thyself to sleep, and
leave thy vain bibble
babble.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Sir Topas!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Maintain no words with him, good
fellow.
Who, I, sir? not I, sir. God be wi' you,
good Sir Topas. Marry,
amen. I will, sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Fool, fool, fool, I say!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Alas, sir, be patient. What say you
sir? I am shent
for speaking to you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Good fool, help me to some light and
some
paper: I tell thee, I am as well in my
wits as any man in
Illyria.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Well-a-day that you were, sir!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
By this hand, I am. Good fool, some
ink, paper
and light; and convey what I will
set down to my
lady: it shall advantage thee
more than ever the bearing
of letter did.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will help you to't. But tell me true,
are you not
mad indeed? or do you but counterfeit?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Believe me, I am not; I tell thee true.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll ne'er believe a madman till I
see his brains.
I will fetch you light and paper
and ink.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Fool, I'll requite it in the highest degree:
I prithee, be gone.

lg.l: I am gone, sir,
And anon, sir,
I'll be with you again,
In a trice,
Like to the old Vice,
Your need to sustain;
Who, with dagger of lath.
In his rage and his wrath,
Cries, ah, ha! to the devil:
Like a mad lad,
Pare thy nails, dad;
Adieu, good man devil.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This is the air; that is the glorious sun;
This pearl she gave me, I do feel't and see't;
And though 'tis wonder that enwraps me thus,
Yet 'tis not madness. Where's Antonio, then?
I could not find him at the Elephant:
Yet there he was; and there I found this credit,
That he did range the town to seek me out.
His counsel now might do me golden service;
For though my soul disputes well with my sense,
That this may be some error, but no madness,
Yet doth this accident and flood of fortune
So far exceed all instance, all discourse,
That I am ready to distrust mine eyes
And wrangle with my reason that persuades me
To any other trust but that I am mad
Or else the lady's mad; yet, if 'twere so,
She could not sway her house, command her followers,
Take and give back affairs and their dispatch
With such a smooth, discreet and stable bearing
As I perceive she does: there's something in't

That is deceivable. But here the lady comes.
Enter OLIVIA and Priest.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Blame not this haste of mine. If you mean well,
Now go with me and with this holy man
Into the chantry by: there, before him,
And underneath that consecrated roof,
Plight me the full assurance of your faith;
That my most jealous and too doubtful soul
May live at peace. He shall conceal it
Whiles you are willing it shall come to note,
What time we will our celebration keep
According to my birth. What do you say?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'll follow this good man, and go with you;
And, having sworn truth, ever will be true.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Then lead the way, good father; and heavens so shine,
That they may fairly note this act of mine! [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
Now, as thou lovest me, let me see
his letter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Good Master Fabian, grant me another
request.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Do not desire to see this letter.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p:
This is, to give a dog, and in recompense
desire
my dog again.
Enter DUKE, VIOLA, CURIO, and Lords.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Belong you to the Lady Olivia, friends?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ay, sir; we are some of her trappings.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I know thee well: how dost thou, my good
fellow?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly, sir, the better for my foes and
the worse
for my friends.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Just the contrary; the better for thy friends.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: No, sir, the worse.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, they praise me and make
an ass of me;
now my foes tell me plainly I
am an ass: so that by my
foes, sir, I profit in
the knowledge of myself, and by my
friends
I am abused: so that, conclusions to be as
kisses, if
your four negatives make your two
affirmatives, why
then, the worse for my
friends and the better for my foes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Why, this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth, sir, no; though it please
you to be
one of my friends.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Thou shalt not be the worse for
me: there's gold.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But that would be double-dealing,
sir, I would
you could make it another.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: O, you give me ill counsel.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Put your grace in your pocket, sir, for
this once,
and let your flesh and blood obey it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Well, I will be so much a sinner, to
be a double-dealer:
there's another.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good
play; and the old
saying is, the third pays for
all: the triplex, sir, is a good
tripping measure;
or the bells of Saint Bennet, sir, may put
you in mind; one, two, three.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
You can fool no more money out of
me at this
throw: if you will let your lady
know I am here to speak
with her, and bring
her along with you, it may awake my
bounty
further.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry, sir, lullaby to your bounty till
I come again.
I go, sir; but I would not have
you to think that
my desire of having is the
sin of covetousness: but, as
you say, sir, let
your bounty take a nap, I will awake it
anon. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Here comes the man, sir, that did rescue me. Enter ANTONIO and Officers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: That face of his I do remember well;
Yet, when I saw it last, it was besmear'd
As black as Vulcan in the smoke of war:
A bawbling vessel was he captain of,
For shallow draught and bulk unprizable;
With which such scathful grapple did he make
With the most noble bottom of our fleet,
That very envy and the tongue of loss
Cried fame and honor on him. What's the matter ?

sp.speaker: First Off.
sp.l: Orsino, this is that Antonio
That took the Phoenix and her fraught from Candy;
And this is he that did the Tiger board,
When your young nephew Titus lost his leg:
Here in the streets, desperate of shame and state,
In private brabble did we apprehend him

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: He did me kindness, sir, drew on my side;
But in conclusion put strange speech upon me:
I know not what 'twas but distraction.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Notable pirate! thou salt-water thief!
What foolish boldness brought thee to their mercies,
Whom thou, in terms so bloody and so dear,
Hast made thine enemies?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Orsino, noble sir,
Be pleased that I shake off these names you give me:
Antonio never yet was thief or pirate,
Though I confess, on base and ground enough,
Orsino's enemy. A witchcraft drew me hither:
That most ingrateful boy there by your side
From the rude sea's enraged and foamy mouth
Did I redeem; a wreck past hope he was:
His life I gave him and did thereto add
My love, without retention or restraint,
All his in dedication; for his sake
Did I expose myself, pure for his love,
Into the danger of this adverse town;
Drew to defend him when he was beset:
Where being apprehended, his false cunning,
Not meaning to partake with me in danger,
Taught him to face me out of his acquaintance,
And grew a twenty years removed thing
While one would wink; denied me mine own purse,
Which I had recommended to his use
Not half an hour before.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: How can this be?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: When came he to this town?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To-day, my lord; and for three months before,
No interim, not a minute's vacancy,

Both day and night did we keep company.
Enter OLIVIA and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
Here comes the countess: now heaven walks
on earth.
But for thee, fellow; fellow, thy words are madness:
Three months this youth hath tended upon me;
But more of that anon. Take him aside.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What would my lord, but that he may not have,
Wherein Olivia may seem serviceable?
Cesario, you do not keep promise with me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Gracious Olivia,—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: What do you say, Cesario? Good my lord,—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My lord would speak; my duty hushes me.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: If it be aught to the old tune, my lord,
It is as fat and fulsome to mine ear
As howling after music.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Still so cruel?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Still so constant, lord.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What, to perverseness? you uncivil lady,
To whose ingrate and unauspicious altars
My soul the faithfull'st offerings hath breathed out
That e'er devotion tender'd! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Even what it please my lord, that shall become him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Why should I not, had I the heart to do it,
Like to the Egyptian thief at point of death,
Kill what I love?—a savage jealousy
That sometine savors nobly. But hear me this:
Since you to non-regardance cast my faith,
And that I partly know the instrument
That screws me from my true place in your favor,
Live you the marble-breasted tyrant still;
But this your minion, whom I know you love,
And whom, by heaven I swear, I tender dearly,
Him will I tear out of that cruel eye,
Where he sits crowned in his master's spite.
Come, boy, with me; my thoughts are ripe in mischief:
I'll sacrifice the lamb that I do love,
To spite a raven's heart within a dove.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And I, most jocund, apt and willingly,
To do you rest, a thousand deaths would die.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Where goes Cesario?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: After him I love
More than I love these eyes, more than my life,
More, by all mores, than e'er I shall love wife.
If I do feign, you witnesses above
Punish my life for tainting of my love!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ay me, detested! how am I beguiled!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Who does beguile you? who does do you wrong?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Hast thou forgot thyself? is it so long?
Call forth the holy father.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Come, away!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Whither, my lord? Cesario, husband, stay.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Husband!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ay, husband: can he that deny?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Her husband, sirrah!

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: No, my lord, not I.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Alas, it is the baseness of thy fear
That makes thee strangle thy propriety:
Fear not, Cesario; take thy fortunes up;
Be that thou know'st thou art, and then thou art

As great as that thou fear'st.
Enter Priest.
O, welcome, father!
Father, I charge thee, by thy reverence,
Here to unfold, though lately we intended
To keep in darkness what occasion now
Reveals before 'tis ripe, what thou dost know
Hath newly pass'd between this youth and me.

sp.speaker: Priest.
sp.l: A contract of eternal bond of love,
Confirm'd by mutual joinder of your hands,
Attested by the holy close of lips,
Strengthen'd by interchangement of your rings;
And all the ceremony of this compact
Seal'd in my function, by my testimony:
Since when, my watch hath told me, toward my grave
I have travell'd but two hours.'

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O thou dissembling cub! what wilt thou be
When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
Or will not else thy craft so quickly grow,
That thine own trip shall be thine overthrow?
Farewell, and take her; but direct thy feet
Where thou and I henceforth may never meet.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My lord, I do protest—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: O, do not swear!

Hold little faith, though thou hast too much fear.
Enter SIR ANDREW.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
For the love of God, a surgeon!
Send one presently
to Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
He has broke my head across and
has given Sir
Toby a bloody coxcomb too: for
the love of God, your
help! I had rather than
forty pound I were at home.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Who has done this, Sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
The count's gentleman, one Cesario:
we took
him for a coward, but he's the
very devil incardinate.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: My gentleman, Cesario?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
'Od's lifelings, here he is! You
broke my head
for nothing; and that that I
did, I was set on to do't by Sir
Toby.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Why do you speak to me? I never hurt you:
You drew your sword upon me without cause;
But I bespake you fair, and hurt you not.

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
If a bloody coxcomb be a hurt,
you have hurt
me: I think you set nothing by
a bloody coxcomb. Enter SIR TOBY and CLOWN.
Here comes Sir Toby halting: you shall hear
more: but if
he had not been in drink, he
would have tickled you
othergates than he did.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
How now, gentleman! how is't with
you?

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
That's all one: has hurt me, and
there's the end on't.
Sot, didst see Dick surgeon,
sot?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O, he's drunk, Sir Toby, an hour
agone; his eyes
were set at eight i' the morning.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Then he's a rogue, and a passy
measures panyn: I
hate a drunken rogue.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Away with him! Who hath made this
havoc
with them?

sp.speaker: Sir And.
sp.p:
I'll help you, Sir Toby, because
we'll be dressed
together.

sp.speaker: Sir To.
sp.p:
Will you help? an ass-head and a
coxcomb and
a knave, a thin-faced knave, a
gull!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Get him to bed, and let his hurt be
look'd to. [Exeunt Clown, Fabian, Sir Toby, and Sir Andrew.
Enter SEBASTIAN.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I am sorry, madam, I have hurt your kinsman;
But, had it been the brother of my blood,
I must have done no less with wit and safety.
You throw a strange regard upon me, and by that
I do perceive it hath offended you:
Pardon me, sweet one, even for the vows
We made each other but so late ago.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: One face, one voice, one habit, and two persons,
A natural perspective, that is and is not!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Antonio, O my dear Antonio!
How have the hours rack'd and tortured me,
Since I have lost thee!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sebastian are you?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Fear'st thou that, Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How have you made division of yourself?
An apple, cleft in two, is not more twin
Than these two creatures. Which is Sebastian?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Most wonderful!

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Do I stand there? I never had a brother;
Nor can there be that deity in my nature,
Of here and every where. I had a sister,
Whom the blind waves and surges have devour'd.
Of charity, what kin are you to me?
What countryman? what name? what parentage?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Of Messaline: Sebastian was my father;
Such a Sebastion was my brother too,
So went he suited to his watery tomb:
If spirits can assume both form and suit
You come to fright us.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A spirit I am indeed;
But am in that dimension grossly clad
Which from the womb I did participate.
Were you a woman, as the rest goes even,
I should my tears let fall upon your cheek,
And say 'Thrice-welcome, drowned Viola!'

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: My father had a mole upon his brow,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And so had mine.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And died that day when Viola from her birth
Had number'd thirteen years.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: O, that record is lively in my soul!
He finished indeed his mortal act
That day that made my sister thirteen years.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: If nothing lets to make us happy both
But this my masculine usurp'd attire,
Do not embrace me till each circumstance
Of place, time, fortune, do cohere and jump
That I am Viola: which to confirm,
I'll bring you to a captain in this town,
Where lie my maiden weeds; by whose gentle help
I was preserved to serve this noble count.
All the occurrence of my fortune since
Hath been between this lady and this lord.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So comes it, lady, you have been mistook:
But nature to her bias drew in that.
You would have been contracted to a maid;
Nor are you therein, by my life, deceived,
You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be not amazed; right noble is his blood.
If this be so, as yet the glass seems true,

I shall have share in this most happy wreck.
[To Viola]
Boy, thou hast said to me a thousand times
Thou never shouldst love woman like to me.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: And all those sayings will I overswear;
And all those swearings keep as true in soul
As doth that orbed continent the fire
That severs day from night.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Give me thy hand;
And let me see thee in thy woman's weeds.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: The captain that did bring me first on shore
Hath my maid's garments: he upon some action
Is now in durance, at Malvolio's suit,
A gentleman, and follower of my lady's.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: He shall enlarge him: fetch Malvolio hither:
And yet, alas, now I remember me,

They say, poor gentleman, he's much distract.
Re-enter CLOWN with a letter, and FABIAN.
A most extracting frenzy of mine own
From my remembrance clearly banish'd his.
How does he, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly, madam, he holds Belzebub at
the stave's end as
well as a man in his case
may do: has here writ a letter to
you; I
should have given 't you to-day morning, but
as a
madman's epistles are no gospels, so it
skills not much
when they are delivered.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Open't, and read it.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Look then to be well edified when the
fool
delivers the madman. [Reads] 'By the
Lord, madam,'—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: How now! art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No, madam, I do but read madness:
an your
ladyship will have it as it ought to be,
you must allow
Vox.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Prithee, read i' thy right wits.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So I do, madonna; but to read his
right wits is to
read thus: therefore perpend,
my princess, and give
ear.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Read it you, sirrah. [To Fabian.

div.p:
'By the Lord, madam, you
wrong me, and
the world shall know it:
though you have put me into
darkness and
given your drunken cousin rule over me,
yet
have I the benefit of my senses as well as your
ladyship.
I have your own letter that induced
me to the
semblance I put on; with the which
I doubt not but to
do myself much right, or
you much shame. Think of
me as you please.
I leave my duty a little unthought of
and speak
out of my injury.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Did he write this?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This savours not much of distraction.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: See him deliver'd, Fabian; bring him hither. [Exit Fabian.
My lord, so please you, these things further thought on,
To think me as well a sister as a wife,
One day shall crown the alliance on't, so please you,
Here at my house and at my proper cost.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Madam, I am most apt to embrace your offer.
[To Viola] Your master quits you; and for your service done him,
So much against the mettle of your sex,
So far beneath your soft and tender breeding,
And since you call'd me master for so long,
Here is my hand: you shall from this time be
Your master's mistress.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l:
A sister! you are she.
Re-enter FABIAN, with MALVOLIO.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is this the madman?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Ay, my lord, this same.
How now, Malvolio!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Madam, you have done me wrong,
Notorious wrong.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Have I, Malvolio? no.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Lady, you have. Pray you, peruse that letter.
You must not now deny it is vour hand:
Write from it, if you can, in hand or phrase;
Or say 'tis not your seal, not your invention:
You can say none of this: well, grant it then
And tell me, in the modesty of honor,
Why you have given me such clear lights of favor,
Bade me come smiling and cross-garter'd to you,
To put on yellow stockings and to frown
Upon Sir Toby and the lighter people;
And, acting this in an obedient hope,
Why have you suffer'd me to be imprison'd,
Kept in a dark house, visited by the priest,
And made the most notorious geck and gull
That e'er invention play'd on? tell me why.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Alas, Malvolio, this is not my writing,
Though, I confess, much like the character:
But out of question 'tis Maria's hand.
And now I do bethink me, it was she
First told me thou wast mad; then camest in smiling,
And in such forms which here were presupposed
Upon thee in the letter. Prithee, be content:
This practice hath most shrewdly pass'd upon thee;
But when we know the grounds and authors of it,
Thou shalt be both the plaintiff and the judge
Of thine own cause.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.l: Good madam, hear me speak,
And let no quarrel nor no brawl to come
Taint the condition of this present hour,
Which I have wonder'd at. In hope it shall not,
Most freely I confess, myself and Toby
Set this device against Malvolio here,
Upon some stubborn and uncourteous parts
We had conceived against him: Maria writ
The letter at Sir Toby's great importance;
In recompense whereof he hath married her.
How with a sportful malice it was follow'd,
May rather pluck on laughter than revenge;
If that the injuries be justly weigh'd
That have on both sides pass'd.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: Alas, poor fool, how have they baffled thee!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, 'some are born great, some
achieve greatness,
and some have greatness
thrown upon them.' I
was one, sir, in this interlude;
one Sir Topas, sir; but that's
all one.
'By the Lord, fool, I am not mad.' But do you
remember?
'Madam, why laugh you at such a
barren rascal?
an you smile not, he's gagged:'
and thus the whirligig
of time brings in his revenges

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'll be revenged on the whole packof you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.l: He hath been most notoriously abused.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Pursue him, and entreat him to a peace:
He hath not told us of the captain yet:
When that is known and golden time convents,
A solemn combination shall be made
Of our dear souls. Meantime, sweet sister,
We will not part from hence. Cesario, come;
For so you shall be, while you are a man;
But when in other habits you are seen,
Orsino's mistress and his fancy's queen. [Exeunt all, except Clown.

lg.l: When that I was and a little tiny boy,
With hey, ho, the wind and the rain,
A foolish thing was but a toy,
For the rain it raineth every day.
But when I came to man's estate,
With hey, ho, &c.
'Gainst knaves and thieves men shut their gate,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came, alas! to wive,
With hey, ho, &c.
By swaggering could I never thrive,
For the rain, &c.
But when I came unto my beds,
With hey, ho, &c.
With toss-pots still had drunken heads,
For the rain, &c.
A great while ago the world begun,
With hey, ho, &c.
But that's all one, our play is done,
And we'll strive to please you every day.
